DataElement.preferredName: Disease or Disorder Hematologic Status Leukemia Status Type
DataElement.preferredDefinition: A description of the hematologic disease status of leukemia.

DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: Any abnormal condition of the body or mind that causes discomfort, dysfunction, or distress to the person affected or those in contact with the person. The term is often used broadly to include injuries, disabilities, syndromes, symptoms, deviant behaviors, and atypical variations of structure and function._Pertaining to or related to the blood and blood-forming organs._A condition or state at a particular time.

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: A definite pathologic process with a characteristic set of signs and symptoms. It may affect the whole body or any of its parts, and its etiology, pathology, and prognosis may be known or unknown.

Concepts.definition: Any abnormal condition of the body or mind that causes discomfort, dysfunction, or distress to the person affected or those in contact with the person. The term is often used broadly to include injuries, disabilities, syndromes, symptoms, deviant behaviors, and atypical variations of structure and function.

Property.preferredDefinition: Pertaining to or related to the blood and blood-forming organs.:A condition or state at a particular time.

Concepts.definition: Pertaining to or related to the blood and blood-forming organs.
A condition or state at a particular time.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: evaluations of the patient and the patient's disease.

ValueDomain.preferredDefinition: A malignant (clonal) hematologic disorder, involving hematopoietic stem cells and characterized by the presence of primitive or atypical myeloid or lymphoid cells in the bone marrow and the blood.  Leukemias are classified as acute or chronic based on the degree of cellular differentiation and the predominant cell type present.  Leukemia is usually associated with anemia, fever, hemorrhagic episodes, and splenomegaly.  Common leukemias include acute myeloid leukemia, chronic myelogenous leukemia, acute lymphoblastic or precursor lymphoblastic leukemia, and chronic lymphocytic leukemia.  Treatment is vital to patient survival; untreated, the natural course of acute leukemias is normally measured in weeks or months, while that of chronic leukemias is more often measured in months or years._A condition or state at a particular time._Type; a subdivision of a particular kind of thing.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Preceding all others in time or space or degree.: The disappearance of all signs of cancer in response to treatment.

Concepts.definition: Preceding all others in time or space or degree.
The disappearance of all signs of cancer in response to treatment.

ValueMeaning.changeDescription: User curated long name to support DCI, Modified RANO, ghd, 04.24.18

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: An operation in which a term denies or inverts the meaning of another term or construction.: An action or administration of therapeutic agents to produce an effect that is intended to alter the course of a pathologic process.

Concepts.definition: An operation in which a term denies or inverts the meaning of another term or construction.
An action or administration of therapeutic agents to produce an effect that is intended to alter or stop a pathologic process.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Preceding all others in time or space or degree.: the return of a sign, symptom, or disease after a remission.

Concepts.definition: Preceding all others in time or space or degree.
The return of a disease after a period of remission.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Coming next after the first in position in space or time or degree or magnitude.: The disappearance of all signs of cancer in response to treatment.  This does not always mean the cancer has been cured.

Concepts.definition: Coming next after the first in position in space or time or degree or magnitude.
The disappearance of all signs of cancer in response to treatment.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Coming next after the first in position in space or time or degree or magnitude.: the return of a sign, symptom, or disease after a remission.

Concepts.definition: Coming next after the first in position in space or time or degree or magnitude.
The return of a disease after a period of remission.

ValueMeaning.preferredName: Greater Than or Equal To Integer::3 Complete Remission
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A statement about the relative size or order of two objects specifying that either both objects are the same in quantity or measure or value or status or that the object of interest exceeds the other object in one of these ways.: A number with no fractional part.::3: The disappearance of all signs of cancer in response to treatment.  This does not always mean the cancer has been cured.

Concepts.definition: A statement about the relative size or order of two objects specifying that either both objects are the same in quantity or measure or value or status or that the object of interest exceeds the other object in one of these ways.
A number with no fractional part, including the negative and positive numbers as well as zero.
The disappearance of all signs of cancer in response to treatment.

PermissibleValues.valueDescription: Greater Than or Equal To Integer::3 Recurrent Disease

ValueMeaning.preferredName: Greater Than or Equal To Integer::3 Recurrent Disease
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A statement about the relative size or order of two objects specifying that either both objects are the same in quantity or measure or value or status or that the object of interest exceeds the other object in one of these ways.: A number with no fractional part.::3: the return of a sign, symptom, or disease after a remission.

Concepts.definition: A statement about the relative size or order of two objects specifying that either both objects are the same in quantity or measure or value or status or that the object of interest exceeds the other object in one of these ways.
A number with no fractional part, including the negative and positive numbers as well as zero.
The return of a disease after a period of remission.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A disease status whereby the patient does not achieve a complete remission. It may not be limited to the first/initial course of therapy; it may represent all courses.

Concepts.definition: A disease status whereby the patient does not achieve a complete remission. It may not be limited to the first/initial course of therapy; it may represent all courses.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: An indication that an individual is receiving something at the present time.: The first choice of treatment for a particular type of cancer.

Concepts.definition: An indication that an individual is receiving something at the present time.
The first choice of treatment for a particular type of cancer.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: the response criteria (includes RECIST and others) and associated documentation of disease.

RepresentationTerm.preferredDefinition: A malignant (clonal) hematologic disorder, involving hematopoietic stem cells and characterized by the presence of primitive or atypical myeloid or lymphoid cells in the bone marrow and the blood.  Leukemias are classified as acute or chronic based on the degree of cellular differentiation and the predominant cell type present.  Leukemia is usually associated with anemia, fever, hemorrhagic episodes and splenomegaly.  Common leukemias include acute myeloid leukemia, chronic myelogenous leukemia, acute lymphoblastic or precursor lymphoblastic leukemia, and chronic lymphocytic leukemia.  Treatment is vital to patient survival; untreated, the natural course of acute leukemias is normally measured in weeks or months, while that of chronic leukemias is more often measured in months or years.:A condition or state at a particular time.:Type; a subdivision of a particular kind of thing.

Concepts.definition: A malignant (clonal) hematologic disorder, involving hematopoietic stem cells and characterized by the presence of primitive or atypical myeloid or lymphoid cells in the bone marrow and the blood. Leukemias are classified as acute or chronic based on the degree of cellular differentiation and the predominant cell type present. Leukemia is usually associated with anemia, fever, hemorrhagic episodes, and splenomegaly. Common leukemias include acute myeloid leukemia, chronic myelogenous leukemia, acute lymphoblastic or precursor lymphoblastic leukemia, and chronic lymphocytic leukemia. Treatment is vital to patient survival; untreated, the natural course of acute leukemias is normally measured in weeks or months, while that of chronic leukemias is more often measured in months or years.
A condition or state at a particular time.
Something distinguishable as an identifiable class based on common qualities.

ReferenceDocuments.name: BRIDG Mapping for CDE:3588591
ReferenceDocuments.description: "PerformedDiagnosis.diseaseStatusCode WHERE PerformedDiagnosis.value = ""acute myologenous leukemia(AML)"" OR ""acute nonlymphocytic leukemia"" AND PerformedDiagnosis.reportedDate IS LESS THAN OR EQUAL TO PerformedSubstanceAdministration.dateRange AND PerformedSubstanceAdministration > DefinedSubstanceAdministration.nameCode = ""Administer Hematopoietic Cell Product{ Transplantation}"""

ReferenceDocuments.name: BRIDG Mapping for CDE 3588591
ReferenceDocuments.description: "PerformedDiagnosis.diseaseStatusCode  WHERE PerformedDiagnosis.value = ""Acute Lymphoblastic Leukemia(ALL)"" AND PerformedDiagnosis.reportedDate IS LESS THAN OR EQUAL TO PerformedSubstanceAdministration.dateRange AND PerformedSubstanceAdministration > DefinedSubstanceAdministration.nameCode = ""Administer Hematopoietic Cell Product{ Transplantation}"""
